Understates: The claim that students who receive free or reduced lunch are "performing just as well" as students who do not understates the actual performance difference between the two groups, as the provided evidence shows that students receiving free or reduced lunch consistently scored worse on average in every subject area tested.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it contradicts the evidence provided, which clearly shows that students receiving free or reduced lunch perform worse on average than those who do not.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that students who receive free or reduced lunch are performing just as well as their counterparts without providing sufficient evidence or data to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the performance difference between students who receive free or reduced lunch and those who do not. It fails to acknowledge other factors that may contribute to the performance disparity, such as socioeconomic disadvantages or limited access to resources.
